channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Well: Researchers Link Longer Work Hours and Stroke Risk
item.description: An analysis of data on more than 600,000 people is the largest study thus far of the relationship between working hours and cardiovascular health.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Russia Sentences Estonian to 15 Years in Disputed Spy Case
item.description: The conviction of a security officer, which was denounced by Estonia and Western nations, reflects tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: Eston Kohver, an Estonian security officer, talking with a lawyer in a Russian court in June. He was convicted of espionage on Wednesday.

item.title: An Architect of the Latest Greek Bailout Navigates Germany’s Dual Roles
item.description: The job of Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble reflects the strains within Germany to enforce its values while also trying to hold a fractious Europe together.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Wall Street Journal Criticizes Iranian Media Accounts Maligning Its Reporter
item.description: The Journal said reports in Iran accusing the newspaper and a correspondent, Farnaz Fassihi, of conspiring against the government were false and scurrilous.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Chinese Report Details Role of Political Connections in Tianjin Blasts
item.description: The state-run news agency described how two major shareholders in a company gained government approvals for the warehouse where the explosions took place.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Displaced residents protested in Tianjin, China, on Wednesday to demand that the government buy back their homes.

item.title: Hague Court to Reconsider Whether Kenya Obstructed Prosecution of President
item.description: An effort to prosecute Uhuru Kenyatta, the Kenyan president, at the International Criminal Court over deadly postelection violence in 2007 collapsed last year.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Letter From India: When Killers Talk, Few in India Seem to Care
item.description: In a documentary, six people explain in great detail how they had shot or carved up scores of people. But the film is not expected to gain much attention.
item.dc:creator: MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Israeli Court Rules to Suspend Palestinian Prisoner’s Detention
item.description: The court said that Mohammad Allan, who has been on a two-month hunger strike, was in such a depleted condition that he no longer posed a security threat.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: A poster of Mohammad Allan, a Palestinian prisoner on a hunger strike, displayed during a protest in Rahat, Israel, on Tuesday calling for his release.

item.title: ISIS Beheads Syrian Antiquities Scholar in Palmyra
item.description: Khalid al-Asaad, who oversaw the sprawling ancient ruins, was beheaded in a public square, according to the Syrian government and Mr. Asaad’s relatives.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Directorate-General of Antiquities and Museums, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Khalid al-Asaad, the retired chief archaeologist of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra.

item.title: Germany Announces Plan to Cope with Migrant Influx
item.description: The country expects up to 800,000 asylum seekers or refugees this year, and its interior minister said that “it is also time for European solutions.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A center for asylum seekers in eastern Germany, near the Polish border. Germany's interior minister says it is impractical in the long term for Germany to absorb some 40 percent of refugees and asylum seekers arriving in Europe.

item.title: Thai Police Seek ‘Foreign Man’ in Bombing of Bangkok Shrine
item.description: They released a sketch of a man with features they characterized as Caucasian, Arab or mixed race and said they believed he had two accomplices.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Buddhist monks prayed on Wednesday for victims of the bombing at the Erawan Shrine in Bangkok.

item.title: China’s Carbon Dioxide Emissions May Have Been Overstated by More Than 10%
item.description: A study finds that the low quality of coal in China, containing less carbon, and its inefficient use means less carbon dioxide was emitted than previously estimated.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The cooling towers of a thermal power plant in Fushun, China. The country’s proposed commitments to curtail emissions are crucial to a new international agreement on global warming.

item.title: Santiago Journal: Indigenous Practices Seep Into Chile’s Health Care Network
item.description: An effort to make the Chilean public health system more inclusive has taken an unusual turn, as non-indigenous patients increasingly look beyond Western medicine.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juanita Huenufil, a Mapuche therapist, heating a drum before morning prayers in a traditional hut called a ruka in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Week After the Tianjin Blasts: What We Know
item.description: The scale of the disaster — in terms of lives lost, environmental pollution, property destruction and economic costs — is beginning to emerge.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An aerial view of what remained of warehouses in Tianjin after the fire and explosions.

item.title: Activist Targeting Modi’s Government Becomes Government’s Target
item.description: Teesta Setalvad, who seeks to hold the Indian prime minister responsible for deadly riots in 2002, has been overwhelmed by attacks emanating from entities controlled by him or his allies.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Indian rights activist Teesta Setalvad, center, with Rupa Mody, left, and Saira Sandhi, who both lost family members during riots in 2002 that killed more than 1,000 people in Gujarat. Ms. Setalvad is campaigning to hold Prime Minister Narendra Modi criminally responsible for the riots.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Blind Faith in China’s Stock Market
item.description: The allure of quick profits tempted many Chinese people to gamble their savings in stocks.
item.dc:creator: YU HUA

item.title: Activist Targeting Modi’s Government Becomes Government’s Target
item.description: Teesta Setalvad, who seeks to hold the Indian prime minister responsible for deadly riots in 2002, has been overwhelmed by attacks emanating from entities controlled by him or his allies.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Indian rights activist Teesta Setalvad, center, with Rupa Mody, left, and Saira Sandhi, who both lost family members during riots in 2002 that killed more than 1,000 people in Gujarat. Ms. Setalvad is campaigning to hold Prime Minister Narendra Modi criminally responsible for the riots.

item.title: Gabon’s President Offers Some of His Wealth ‘to the People’
item.description: The move by Ali Ben Bongo, one of Africa’s wealthiest leaders, was heralded by his circle but met with skepticism from critics who pointed out the legal and political pressure he faces.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President Ali Ben Bongo of Gabon.

item.title: Tony Gleaton, 67, Dies, Leaving Legacy in Pictures of Africans in the Americas
item.description: Mr. Gleaton traveled light, by bus, without assistants, complex equipment or luxury lodgings, to document the lives of black cowboys and create images of the African diaspora in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Tony Gleaton in a 1998 photograph. His career began in the fashion industry but quickly took a sharp turn.

item.title: One Palestinian’s Refusal to Eat Puts Israel in a Bind
item.description: The case has received extraordinary attention because it unfolded as Israel passed a law concerning the force-feeding of hunger strikers.
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Supporters held a photo of Mohammad Allan, the Palestinian hunger striker, during a rally on Tuesday in southern Israel.
